author: s1na
content:
> I think I've read somewhere that adding something related to witnesses to the block headers is being considered
<@!709839792308748308> yeah a hash of the witness (or access list) might be added to the block header regardless of code merkleization.
Well here you're talking about light clients which have different security assumptions than stateless clients. You might be right that some light clients (depending on their security requirements) might be happy without code merkle proofs if the block has been buried deep enough in the chain.
Stateless clients however validate blocks independently, like a normal client. And there the problem is that without the merkle proofs (only chunks + bitmaps) they can't verify the correctness of the contract bytecode.

author: s1na
content:
<@!709839792308748308> Looking forward to reading it when you come up with something!
It might be difficult to overcome the need for those proofs though. To reduce the hashes sizes Vitalik proposed using polynomial commitments which have constant (and small) proof sizes. That's an interesting direction to explore

author: s1na
content: hm can't really think of a resource on that. I remember it only being discussed on some calls? top of my head the reason for adding a hash is to have a canonical version of the witness and to make it harder for clients to serve incomplete or too large witnesses
